answers: Greek fire [prompt on "sea fire", "water fire", or "fire"]
parts: This mysterious Byzantine weapon may have been invented by Kallinikos. Possibly created using naphtha, it was used to destroy various Muslim fleets and could reportedly continue to burn while floating on water.

This medieval siege engine was used to fling heavy projectiles. Unlike catapults, it used the energy from a counterweight to launch objects, but like catapults it became obsolete after gunpowder was popularized.

This Byzantine ruler was described as inventing several types of trebuchets during the 1097 Siege of Nicaea. This ruler's request of aid from Europe triggered the First Crusade, and his daughter Anna wrote a notable biography of him.

answers: Joseph Vissarionovich Stalin [or Iosef Vissarionovich Dzhugashvili]
parts: Identify this play set in a boardinghouse run by Kostilyoff, who is killed by the thief Vaska Pepel. It centers on a vagabond named Luka.
This Russian playwright, a founder of socialist realism who wrote his novel Mother while traveling through the Adirondack Mountains, penned The Lower Depths

In 1931, this figure autographed a copy of Gorky's "A Girl and Death", claiming that it was "stronger than Goethe's Faust". This Soviet leader was described as a "Kremlin Caucasian" who forged "rules and decrees like horseshoes" in an "Epigram" by Osip Mandelstam.

answers: Helen Hunt Jackson [or Helen Fiske; accept just "Hunt," which was her sole last name for a while]
parts: This marine biologist and author of The Sea Around Us launched modern environmentalism in the United States by publishing Silent Spring.
This author wrote the novel Ramona and tract A Century of Dishonor to publicize the plight of Native Americans in the late 19th century.
The 1948 publication of The Seven Storey Mountain, an autobiography by this Trappist Monk of Kentucky's Gethsemani Abbey, ignited American interest in religious meditation.

answers: Lower Egypt [do not prompt on or accept "Egypt"]
parts: Name this falcon deity who vanquished Set, the great enemy of his father Osiris.
One form of Horus, Horus-Behdety, fathered a child with this cow-headed goddess, who once performed an erotic dance to cheer up Ra.
Another view of the Horus-Set conflict is that it symbolized this region's conquest by its counterpart. Rulers of this region wore a red crown known as the Deshret.
Name this Puccini opera set in Japan, in which the title character, Cio-Cio San, is impregnated and abandoned by the American sailor Benjamin Franklin Pinkerton.
After her maid Suzuki warns her that Pinkerton may never return, Cio-Cio San sings this aria, in which she imagines seeing the smoke of a returning ship and reuniting with Pinkerton.
This other Puccini opera features the act two aria "Musetta's Waltz," and ends with Rodolfo crying over the dead body of Mimi.
Name these astronomical bodies that consist of an event horizon surrounding a gravitational singularity.
This physicist names a type of radiation given off by black holes. He also disagreed with Leonard Susskind over interpretations of the information paradox.
Hawking radiation occurs when this event happens near the event horizon. In this process, a particle and antiparticle are spontaneously created from a photon.

answers: Charles Cornwallis, 1st Marquess Cornwallis [or Viscount Brome or The Earl Cornwallis]
parts: Identify this general who suffered a severe defeat at the Battle of Camden. With Benedict Arnold, he had earlier defeated John Burgoyne at the Battle of Saratoga.
The overall commander of the British forces at Camden was this general who also saw his position bombarded by the Comte de Grasse and the French navy at the Battle of Yorktown.
The Green Dragoons or British Legion was led by this infamous loyalist colonel, nicknamed the "Butcher." Most of his contingent was captured at the later Battle of Cowpens.

answers: John Winslow Irving [or John Wallace Blunt, Jr.; the work is A Prayer for Owen Meany]
parts: Name this collection of stories narrated by their author, Tim O'Brien

The Things They Carried is set during this war, fought in a country where Alden Pyle advocated for a "third force" before its onset in Graham Greene's The Quiet American. Its outcome is flipped in the alternate history of Watchmen.

The title character of one of this author's works dies saving some Vietnamese children from a grenade. Earlier in that work by this man, the title character had accidentally killed Tabitha Wheelwright with a foul ball.

answers: integrates into the genome [or inserts, joins, fuses, jumps into, becomes part of, puts itself in, etc]
parts: Name these small loops of DNA found in bacteria, originally discovered by Joshua Lederberg. The F one encodes for a fertility factor, and the R one codes genes that confer antibiotic resistance.
The F plasmid confers the ability to transfer genetic information by this mechanism, in which a sex pilus is extended between two bacteria.

High frequency of recombination or Hfr strains use mating bridges to transfer genetic material. Hfr strains are created when the F plasmid does this with respect to the bacterial genome, which is also done by lysogenic phages.

answers: The Return of the Prodigal Son
parts: Identify this artist better known for Aristotle with a Bust of Homer.

This Rembrandt painting's nickname comes from the varnish that has darkened the image. A man in a red sash gestures at a man in a yellow suit in the foreground of this group portrait of the Company of Captain Frans Banning Cocq
In this late religious painting by Rembrandt, a bearded man wearing a red jacket comforts the title character, who is depicted kneeling and wearing tattered clothes with his back to the viewer.
Name this city, which was defended on "La Noche Triste."
Tenochtitlan was the capital of this people, who were ruled by Montezuma and controlled central Mexico when Cortes arrived.
This ritual practice of the Aztecs was initiated by emperor Tlacaelel, who took captives for sacrifice from Tlaxcala after small battles. These rituals took the place of full-scale warfare.
Identify this novel composed of 690 sonnets, which centers on a group of yuppies living in San Francisco.
The Golden Gate was written by this Indian author, who detailed Rupa Mehra's attempts to find the title figure for her daughter Lata in his incredibly long novel A Suitable Boy.
The Golden Gate was written in "Onegin stanzas", which take their name from their use in this Russian author's Eugene Onegin.
Name these gods and spirits worshipped in Shinto, which often correspond to features in the natural world of Japan. The chief one is the sun goddess Amaterasu.
This brother of Amaterasu and Tsukuyomi offended her by flinging a flayed horse into her abode. This slayer of an eight-headed serpent is the kami of the sea and storms.

Amaterasu handed down one of these objects, along with the Kusanagi blade and a string of beads, among three imperial regalia to the Japanese emperors. Another is embedded in an Aztec jaguar god's foot or chest
Name this Czech composer whose ninth symphony in E minor is called "From the New World."
Inspired by the Hungarian Dances of his friend Johannes Brahms, Dvorak composed these sixteen pieces based on the music of his native Bohemia.

Following the death of his daughter Josefa, Dvorak composed this religious work, a setting of a hymn to the Virgin Mary. Giovanni Pergolesi composed a setting of the same text for soprano, alto, and strings.
Controversy continues over whether Saif al-Islam Gaddafi should stand trial before the ICC or be tried by the new government of this country, which his father used to rule.
In April 2012, this former Liberian president was convicted by the ICC of 11 counts of crimes against humanity associated with the civil wars in Liberia and Sierra Leone.

This country's richest citizen and former deputy prime minister is among four men who will stand trial before the ICC for orchestrating ethnic violence in the wake of this country's 2007 presidential election, in which the Orange Democratic Movement lost because of probable fraud.

answers: Bowen's reaction series [Prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this diagram divided into discontinuous and continuous branches, which sorts minerals by their crystallization temperature.
The continuous branch of Bowen's reaction series moves from plagioclase feldspars that are rich in sodium to those rich in this element, whose carbonate is a principal component of limestone.
At the end of the discontinuous branch is this mineral, whose gem-grade variety is called peridot. Its solid solution series contains forsterite and fayalite.

answers: flatterers [or those who engage in flattery]
fortune [or Fortuna; accept synonyms such as luck]
parts: This Italian scholar wrote The Prince and dedicated it to Lorenzo de' Medici
In a late chapter of The Prince, Machiavelli advises a middle road between ignoring all advice and relying on the counsel of these individuals, who might take advantage of self-absorbed princes.

This quality is contrasted with prudence throughout The Prince. Machiavelli compares it to a woman who must be beaten if necessary. In an earlier work, Boethius compared it to a goddess spinning a wheel.

Identify this chemical technique which attempts to find the amount of an analyte in a solution by dripping in a standard solution. Finding the concentration of an acid by adding a base is a common example.
Acid-base titrations commonly use this graduated cylindrical piece of glassware with a stopcock on the bottom

Another piece of glassware with a stopcock is a separatory funnel, which is commonly used in this procedure. In this procedure, a sample is purified by putting an immiscible aqueous and organic phase together and removing the phase containing the product you want.

answers: Sir Robert Walpole, 1st Earl of Oxford
The Prime Minister of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
Kingdom of Poland [or Polska; or War of Polish Succession]
parts: Identify this politician, active during the reigns of George I and George II. He was forced out of power for opposing the War of Jenkins' Ear
Robert Walpole was the first man to hold this post. The holder of this post lives at 10 Downing Street.
Robert Walpole is credited with keeping England out of this country's 1733 to 1738 succession war, which followed the death of Augustus the Strong.
Name this set of eighty-nine sonnets, written to correspond to the Scriptural readings prescribed by the Book of Common Prayer for the days leading up to the author's marriage to Elizabeth Boyle.
This English poet wrote the Amoretti, but he may be better known for describing Archimago and Duessa's attempts to waylay the Redcrosse Knight in his epic The Faerie Queen.
Elizabeth I was the inspiration for this title character of The Faerie Queen, who sends the Redcrosse Knight on his quest to liberate Una's kingdom from a monstrous dragon.

answers: point of inflection [or inflection point; anti-prompt "saddle point"]
parts: If a differentiable function has a minimum or maximum along an interval, Rolle's Theorem guarantees that its first derivative, and therefore its slope, will equal this value at the extremum.
A function's second derivative equals 0 and changes sign from positive to negative or vice versa at this kind of point, which is neither a maximum nor minimum.

To find extrema of a multivariable function along a constraint curve, these values, symbolized lambda, are found. The product of this value and the constraint curve's gradient equals the original function's gradient.

answers: Quo Vadis: A Narrative of the Time of Nero [or Quo vadis: Powiesc z czasow Nerona]
Edward George Earle Lytton Bulwer-Lytton, 1st Baron Lytton
parts: Robert Graves wrote two historical novels about this Roman emperor. In those novels, this emperor informs the reader of his knowledge of Etruscan and describes the death of his predecessor, Caligula.

This Henryk Sienkiewicz novel, set during the reign of Nero, sees Marcus Vinicius convert to Christianity after hearing a speech given by Saint Peter. Vinicius and his lover Lygia flee to Sicily near the end of this novel.

The eruption of Mount Vesuvius saves Glaucus from death in the Coliseum in this British author's novel The Last Days of Pompeii. His other novels include Paul Clifford, which infamously begins "It was a dark and stormy night".

answers: Battle of Teutoberger Forest [or Teutoberger Wald]
eagles [or aquilae, I guess, even though the works mentioned are in English]
parts: Name this 9 CE slaughter, in which the Cherusci leader Hermann destroyed the Roman army of Publius Quinctilius Varus
This author of The Lives of the Caesars depicts Augustus crying out "give me back my legions!" upon learning of the disaster at Teutoberger Wald.
In the book and miniseries I, Claudius, Augustus more memorably demands to know the location of these items, the symbolic figures of birds which stood atop the Roman battle standards.
